xxl.cursors
Class HashGrouper

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.HashGrouper
public class HashGrouper
extends Object
implements Cursor

A HashGrouper partitions input data into groups (strict evaluation).
When the HashGrouper is initialized a new HashMap is created. The input data is partitioned concerning this HashMap by invoking the user-defined function on the given cursor's elements.
A HashGrouper calls next() on the input-Cursor until hasNext() returns false.
Every entry in this HashMap consists of a value and a LinkedList where the cursor's elements are added to.
This means that the HashGrouper partitions the data physically.
A Function is used to compute the value of an object. With regard to this value a bucket in the HashMap is assigned, i.e. a new group starts.

A call to next returns a Cursor pointing to the next group (the next bucket in the HashMap).

Note: An Iterator or a PeekIterator given to a HashGrouper's constructor is wrapped to a Cursor.

Example usage: 


 	HashGrouper hashGrouper = new HashGrouper(
 		new Enumerator(21),
 			new Function () {
 				public Object invoke (Object next) {
 					return new Integer(((Integer)next).intValue() % 5);
 				}
 			}
 	);
 	while(hashGrouper.hasNext()) {
 		Cursor bucket = (Cursor)hashGrouper.next(); // cursor pointing to the next group
 		while(bucket.hasNext())
 			System.out.print(bucket.next()+"; ");
 		System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
 	}
 	hashGrouper.close();
This example creates a new HashGrouper by applying the Function to the objects of an Enumerator. So a HashMap is created with the values 0,...,4 and their buckets. Every entry in this HashMap consists of a value and a LinkedList (bucket) where the cursor's elements are added to.
The implementation of the next method is as follows: 


 	Map hashMap = new HashMap();

 	while (cursor.hasNext()) {
		Object object = cursor.next();
		Object value = function.invoke(object);
		List list = (List)hashMap.get(value);

		if (list==null)
			hashMap.put(value, list = new LinkedList());
		list.add(object);
	}
	groups = new IteratorCursor(hashMap.values().iterator());
A collection is returned by applying the method values() on the HashMap. This collection contains references to all LinkedLists (buckets) used in the HashMap. The method iterator() invoked on this collection returns the elements as an Iterator, which is wrapped to an IteratorCursor, namely the result-Cursor groups.
This result-Cursor is handed out to the caller of next. In the shown use case this cursor is printed to the output-stream, i.e. the elements contained in the buckets were printed out.
The generated output is as follows: 
 	4; 9; 14; 19;
 	3; 8; 13; 18;
 	2; 7; 12; 17;
 	1; 6; 11; 16;
 	0; 5; 10; 15; 20;
The partitions concerning the function (object modulo 5) are represented correctly.

See Also:
Cursor, Function, Iterator, Map, HashMap, List, LinkedList

Method Detail

init

protected void init()
Initializes the HashGrouper by creating a new HashMap.
Partitions the input data concerning this HashMap by invoking the user-defined function on the cursor's elements.
Every entry in this HashMap consists of a key and a LinkedList where the cursor's elements are added to.
The implementation is as follows: 


		Map hashMap = new HashMap();

		while (cursor.hasNext()) {
			Object object = cursor.next();
			Object value = function.invoke(object);
			List list = (List)hashMap.get(value);

			if (list==null)
				hashMap.put(value, list = new LinkedList());
			list.add(object);
		}
		groups = new IteratorCursor(hashMap.values().iterator());
A collection is returned by applying the method values() on the HashMap. This collection contains references to all LinkedLists (buckets) used in the HashMap. The method iterator() invoked on this collection returns the elements as an Iterator which wrapped to an IteratorCursor, namely the result-Cursor groups.

close

public void close()
           throws NoSuchElementException
Closes the HashGrouper. Signals the HashGrouper to cleanup resources, close files, etc.
After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results.
Multiple calls to close() do not have any effect, i.e. if close() was called the HashGrouper remains in the state "closed".
Implemented by closing the given cursor.
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
This happens when the result-Cursor groups has more elements.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the HashGrouper has more elements, otherwise false.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration in this case a cursor.
A new IteratorCursor is returned by calling the next method on the result-Cursor groups. More detailed:
This next method invoked on the result-Cursor groups returns a reference to a list, because the result-Cursor consists of references of list. The method iterator() is applied on this list and the returned Iterator-object is wrapped to an IteratorCursor.
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This operation is not supported by HashGroupers, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by the HashGrouper.

remove

public void remove()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This operation is not supported by HashGroupers, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the HashGrouper.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the HashGrouper to its initial state. (optional operation)
That means the reset method of the input-Cursor and the init method of the HashGrouper is called.
So the caller is able to traverse the underlying collection again.
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the input-Cursor.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns false because HashGroupers do not support the peek- operation.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
false if the peek operation is not supported by the HashGrouper, otherwise true.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This operation is not supported by HashGroupers, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the HashGrouper.
